Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Expert Knowledge of Nuclear Materials and the Development of Atomic Energy Agency Policies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Under the supervision of Josephe Masco at the University of Chicago, Anna Weichselbraun will examine the International Atomic Energy Agency, the 'sole arbiter in the regulation of global nuclear technology,' in its production of legitimacy and communication of 'technical independence.' Making and performing technoscientific expertise lies at the heart of this independence and associated bureaucratic authority, and the research design carefully crafts its questions to probe those spheres of activity and their documentary trails. Through a 10-month ethnographic study at the International Atomic Energy Agency, a linguistic analysis of 150-200 documents including annual reports, safeguards statements, information circulars, general conference documents, and press releases, and interviews with members and interactional analysis of their consensus-building activities, the Co-PI will identify and document the processes whereby IAEA staff work to obtain internal techno-legal consensus and international political consensus among governing bodies like the UN and its member states.

This project lies at the intersection of cultural anthropology and science and technology studies. This interdisciplinary research will produce a better understanding of the unique and powerful role the IAEA plays in international politics and policy and contribute a nuanced view into the nuclear industry and its regulation. The results will be disseminated to practitioner, policy, and academic audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research grant contributed to the support of 27 months of in-depth ethnographic research on the changing role of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), commonly referred to in the media as the UN’s “nuclear watchdog”, in response to a changing political world. The research focused (1) on communication and (2) on the training of safeguards inspectors.

For the first part of the research, the co-PI analyzed the speeches made, documents drafted, training courses and endless meetings held in pursuit of the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons. Initial findings show that the IAEA has developed a highly specialized way of articulating the problem of controlling nuclear technologies. This specialized way of speaking about the control of nuclear technologies has emerged out of a complex interplay between the growing organization and the nation-states that sought to influence its functioning. An additional element of influence in this ecosystem of nuclear control are a number of publications and advocacy organizations that seek to shape the discourse, sometimes even by questioning implicit assumptions.

For the second part of the research, the co-PI observed training courses by which new recruits learn to become nuclear safeguards inspectors, and also conducted interviews with a variety of inspectors about their work. The work of safeguards inspector is rare in the world (there are also inspectors at the European nuclear safeguards organization, EURATOM) and requires a specialized curriculum. While some of the verification techniques also exist outside of the safeguards universe, most of the tools and techniques used by IAEA safeguards inspectors have been especially developed for the purpose of nuclear safeguards verification. The particular technical expertise that the IAEA holds in safeguards verification makes the organization uniquely suited for verifying, for example, the agreement under negotiation between Western powers and the Islamic Republic of Iran.

The intellectual merit of this research includes showing that current ways of speaking about the control of nuclear technologies have been and continue to be historically shaped. This recognition is vital for broadening the scope of the conversation about the control of nuclear technologies in the present, and potentially offering innovative solutions to age-old problems. By contributing original research findings on the IAEA to policy debates about the organization’s role, this research will have a broader impact on global politics beyond academia and scholarship. The co-PI will submit relevant findings to widely read publications on nuclear policy and politics.
